repository.corpname: University of Washington Libraries Special Collections

did.unittitle: John H. Eyer papers

physdesc.extent: 18.45 cubic feet (17 boxes) plus 1 oversize folder

did.abstract: Papers of John H. Eyer, organizer, international representative, and training specialist for the International Brotherhood of Pulp, Sulphite and Paper Mill Workers from circa 1951-1964 and International Representative and Job Analysis Program Chair of the Association of Western Pulp and Paper Workers beginning in 1964.

bioghist.p: John H. Eyer (1906-1986) was an organizer, international representative and training specialist based in Portland, Oregon, for the International Brotherhood of Pulp, Sulphite and Paper Mill Workers (IBPSandPMW) from about 1951-1964. Eyer became training specialist in 1956 which emerged into a permanent position as Representative of the International’s West Coast Research and Education Department in 1957, traveling frequently to locals across the West Coast. Part of this work also included the performance of job analyses, evaluating wages and contracts of locals within the union. At this time, he became a confidant of Research and Education head, George W. Brooks, who figured prominently in the internal campaign for reform, and whose forced resignation in 1961 precipitated the formation of the Rank and File Movement for Democratic Action (RFMDA). An organization created by dissatisfied members of the International, the RFMDA had participation from members of paper worker locals across the United States and even parts of Canada. This reform movement was the catalyst for the formation of new union, the Association of Western Pulp and Paper Workers (AWPPW) in 1964. Along with many members in favor of the reform, John Eyer moved over to the rebel union, AWPPW, becoming an International Representative and chairing its Job Analysis Program. He also served as General Vice President of the AWPPW in the late 1960s. In addition to union involvement, he was also active in the City Club of Portland and served on the Executive Boards of the American Civil Liberties Union of Oregon and the World Without War Council of Portland.

John Howard Eyer was born August 28, 1906 to Mildred Neal and Wilson Eyer. John also had an older brother named Lowell. In June 1930, he married Alice Meisel. John and Alice gave birth to daughter Janet Helen Eyer, who later gave birth to his granddaughter, Susan. Alice Eyer passed away in 1969. John Eyer married again sometime in the 1970s to Rosa Millo, Recording Secretary of AWPPW Local 644 in Everett, Washington and Secretary-Treasurer of the AWPPW Northern Washington and Alaska Area Council. John Eyer passed away in 1986.

list.item: Accession No. 3932-001, John H. Eyer papers, 1930-1986
Accession No. 3932-002, John H. Eyer papers, 1967-1969

scopecontent.p: Correspondence, negotiation files, agreements, subject files, newsletters, court papers, and other material, relating to Eyer's activities as international representative of International Brotherhood of Pulp, Sulphite, and Paper Mill Workers, based in Portland, Or., organizer at mills in the Pacific Northwest during the 1950s, and his later work in the union's Research and Education Dept., where he was in charge on the West Coast. Papers also document the reform movement in the union, including the controversy over the forced resignation of George W. Brooks, head of Research and Education Dept., 1961, resulting in formation of Rank and File Movement for Democratic Action within the union, revolt of West Coast locals and formation of West Coast Pulp and Paper Workers, 1964, in which Eyer served as general vice-president from 1965-1968. Includes files of Burt D. Wells, secretary/treasurer of Rank and File Movement for Democratic Action, and other leaders. Major correspondent is John P. Burke.

odd.p: Forms part of the Labor Archives of Washington.

prefercite.p: Labor Archives of Washington, University of Washington Libraries, Special Collections, John H. Eyer papers, 3932-001 [or 002], box number, folder number.

accessrestrict.p: Collection is open for research but records stored offsite; advance notice is required for use.

userestrict.p: Creator's literary rights transferred to the University of Washington Libraries.

processinfo.p: Processed by Assistant Labor Archivist Crystal Rodgers.

Processing completed in March 2018. Both accessions of the collection were rehoused, including refoldering and reboxing. Preservation issues were addressed, including preservation photocopies made of records printed on thermofax and other vulnerable copy paper as well as several documents showing signs of dormant mold from water damage, rusty fasteners removed and replaced with plasticlips, photographs sleeved, interleaving of acid free paper between news clippings and surrounding documents, occasional weeding of duplication unless kept to maintain context, and folders arranged into series and subseries physically and intellectually of the first accession. See the separated material note for information about separation of 2 groupings of materials in the first accession.

separatedmaterial.p:
Due to the following collections' distinctiveness as bodies of records belonging to Burt D. Wells and Rosa M. Eyer respectively, and the materials' historical significance, these collections were separated from the first accession of the John H. Eyer papers during processing in December 2017.
Burt D. Wells papers (Collection No. 6176)
Rosa M. Eyer papers (Collection No. 6178)

did.unittitle: John H. Eyer papers

physdesc.extent: 18.24 cubic feet (16 boxes) plus 1 oversize folder

scopecontent.p: This accession spans the years 1930-1986 and consist primarily of records created or compiled by John Eyer during his work as an educator and representative for the International Brotherhood of Pulp, Sulphite and Paper Mill Workers and the Association of Western Pulp and Paper Workers. Some material related to the United Papermakers and Paperworkers union is also included. These records feature John Eyer’s involvement with a variety of paper worker locals across the West Coast, from British Columbia to Southern California, including the performance of job analyses, as well as union local and parent organization engagement with major paper companies, such as Weyerhaeuser, Crown Simpson, and Georgia-Pacific. This accession also highlights tensions between the International and its membership where a faction of members formed the Rank and File Movement for Democratic Action (RFMDA) which emerged into rebel union, Association of Western Pulp and Paper Workers in 1964. Also included is a small series of personal papers of Eyer’s consisting of records related to his non-union organizational involvement, family correspondence and birth and death records, and information on Oregon state and national politics.

Materials consist of a large quantity of correspondence to and from Eyer and other International and AWPPW officers and rank and file members, as well as reports; meeting minutes; grievance and arbitration files; contract agreements and constitutions; flyers, pamphlets, and other ephemera; Eyer's handwritten notes and article drafts; news clippings, newsletters, and full newspaper publications, primarily that published by paper worker locals; and several photographs (maintained in their original arrangement and noted in the collection inventory). Subject matter includes strikes; contract negotiations and collective bargaining, including the Uniform Labor Agreement; wages, including union attempts to address the gender pay gap; health insurance, pensions, and other benefits; job analyses of union locals; education and union training programs; arbitration and grievances; paper mill water pollution; election of officers; and elections for union representation.

Note- there is considerable overlap and potential duplication of material across the series in this accession but are maintained in their original arrangement in order to preserve the varied reasons why and how these records were kept. For more detailed description of each series, please see the collection inventory below.

accessrestrict.p: Collection is open for research but records stored offsite; advance notice is required for use

acqinfo.p: Donated by Rosa Millo Eyer, September 14, 1987.

arrangement.p: The collection is arranged into the following series:

item.emph: SERIES 2: INTERNATIONAL BROTHERHOOD OF PULP, SULPHITE AND PAPER MILL WORKERS
Subseries C: Secretary Francis Hannigan, Local 242 (Portland, OR)
Subseries D: Vice President John Sherman
SERIES 3: ASSOCIATION OF WESTERN PULP AND PAPER WORKERS
Subseries E: Representative John R. Swanson, Northern Washington and Alaska Area Council
SERIES 6: PAPER WORKER ORGANIZATIONS AND COUNCILS
Subseries C: Subject Files: State and National Politics

scopecontent.p: Contains assorted records, arranged in alphabetical order by city, from individual paper worker union locals along the West Coast. Locals are primarily affiliated with the International Brotherhood of Pulp, Sulphite and Paper Mill Workers; however, the United Papermakers and Paperworkers and Association of Western Pulp and Paper Workers are also represented in this series.

unittitle.emph: INTERNATIONAL BROTHERHOOD OF PULP, SULPHITE AND PAPER MILL WORKERS

scopecontent.p: Contains correspondence to and from local and International officers of the IBPSandPMW; correspondence, meeting minutes, photographs, publications, and other records from conventions, conferences, and executive board meetings; Local 242 Secretary Francis Hannigan and International Vice President John Sherman correspondence records; company contracts; and other assorted records documenting activities of the International.

unittitle.emph: ASSOCIATION OF WESTERN PULP AND PAPER WORKERS

scopecontent.p: Contains assorted records from the AWPPW, including officer and committee correspondence and reports; meeting minutes; material related to collective bargaining, negotiations, and the Uniform Labor Agreement; arbitration and grievances; officer elections, speeches given, and voting on constitutional changes and local union resolutions at conventions; reports and correspondence from regional councils, including a series specific to the activities of Representative John R. Swanson of the Northern Washington and Alaska Area Council; union publications; records related to attempts of the AWPPW to organize in the Southeast region of the U.S.; officer rosters; and other records related to AWPPW activities.

scopecontent.p: Contains correspondence; news clippings; pamphlets and booklets; contract agreements, including drafts with notes; minutes; reports; legal materials, including National Labor Relations Board case records; and several photographs documenting relations between major paper companies and paper worker unions. Subject matter includes elections; collective bargaining and negotiations, including decisions of locals to withdraw from the Uniform Labor Agreement; job promotions and benefits; grievances and arbitration; strikes; and investigations into paper mill water pollution. Subseries A-I are arranged by company name. Subseries J relates specifically to pensions and K to arbitration cases.

scopecontent.p: Contains legal files, including exhibit records from the consolidated 1964 Supreme Court case where the International and the United Papermakers and Paperworkers both filed complaints against the Uniform Labor Agreement Committee, Association of Western Pulp and Paper Workers, and AWPPW President William R. Perrin. Records document the formation of the Rank and File Movement for Democratic Action by dissatisfied members of the International in the late 1950s which resulted in the creation of the AWPPW as well as rising tensions between the International and the AWPPW. Files include news clippings, newsletters, and other published material; correspondence; reports; handbooks; Uniform Labor Agreement material; meeting minutes; and depositions and Supreme Court briefs.

scopecontent.p: Subseries A contains reference files of labor-specific material, including correspondence, news clippings, reports, and literature from other unions. Subseries B contains reference files specific to investigations into paper mill water pollution in the Puget Sound, including government reports, news clippings and other published material, and drafts of an article written by John Eyer.

scopecontent.p: Contains material documenting John Eyer’s personal live outside of his work with paper worker unions, including correspondence, studies, and other material from Oregon and Portland-based organizations that Eyer was involved in; family papers, including letters to and from family members as well as marriage and death records of his first wife Alice Eyer; and subject files on Oregon state and national politics, including correspondence from Senators and Representatives as well as material from election and legislative campaigns.
